Rusija uresničila namero o oblikovanju lastnega interneta

04 Nov 2019, 13:43

V lanskem letu so v Rusiji sprejel odločitev, da morajo vsa telekomunikacijska podjetja v državni lasti izvesti posebno vajo, ki vključuje popoln odklop od svetovnega spleta. S to vajo želi Rusija dejansko preveriti, kako neodvisna ali odvisna je od interneta. To bo tudi podlaga za oceno, ali se lahko država popolnoma izolira od svetovnega spleta v primeru kibernetskega napada.
Poleg obrambe pred zunanjimi hekerskimi napadi morajo ruski telekomunikacijski operaterji vzpostaviti lastno infrastrukturo, ki jo potrebujejo za zagotavljanje dostopa do svetovnega spleta preko tako imenovanih kontrolnih točk. Nadzorna zvezna svetovalna agencija Roskomnadzor (The Federal Service for Supervision of Communications, Information Technology and Mass Media) pa bo poskrbela, da se na spletu ne bodo izvajale nezakonite dejavnosti. Hkrati bo tudi nadzirala, da bodo vse povezave med ruskimi uporabniki ostale znotraj meja države, namesto da bi "potovale" po strežnikih po vsem svetu, kjer bi promet lahko kdo prestregel in ga celo spremenil.
Za uresničitev omenjenega načrta so ruske oblasti nedavno uveljavili zakon, ki dejansko zagotavlja zakonske možnosti za popolno ukinitev svetovnega spleta v državi. Ruska država ima sedaj popoln tehnični nadzor nad internetom, kar dejansko pomeni, da lahko sedaj ruska država izvaja neposreden nadzor na uporabniki svetovnega spleta, in sicer tako zasebnimi kot poslovnimi.
Ruski internetni promet bo usmerjen skozi osrednje vozlišče v državi, katerega infrastruktura še ni zgrajena. Ponudniki internetnih storitev morajo namreč še namestiti opremo, ki jo potrebujejo za prehod. To bi se lahko zgodilo že v naslednjih nekaj mesecih, saj je pritisk ruske vlade nadvse visok.



Povezave: Nytimes

Russia fulfilled its intention to create its own Internet

04 Nov 2019, 12:43

Last year in Russia, it was decided that all state-owned telecommunications companies must carry out a special exercise involving a complete disconnection from the World Wide Web. With this exercise, Russia wants to actually check how independent or dependent it is on the Internet. It will also provide a basis for assessing whether a country can completely isolate itself from the World Wide Web in the event of a cyber attack.
In addition to defending against external hacking attacks, Russian telecommunications operators must set up their own infrastructure that they need to provide access to the World Wide Web through so-called checkpoints. The Federal Agency for Communications, Information Technology and Mass Media's Roskomnadzor, an oversight agency, will ensure that no illegal activity is carried out online. At the same time, it will also ensure that all connections between Russian users remain within the country's borders, instead of "traveling" to servers around the world where traffic could be intercepted and even changed.
In order to implement the plan, the Russian authorities have recently enacted a law that actually provides legal options for the complete elimination of the world wide web in the country. The Russian state now has full technical control of the Internet, which means that the Russian state can now exercise direct control over the Internet users, both private and business.
Russian Internet traffic will be routed through a central hub in a country whose infrastructure has not yet been built. ISPs have yet to install the equipment they need to transition. This could happen in the next few months, as Russian government pressure is too high.
